lines.text: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner. When you sally upon him, speak what terrible language you will: though you understand it not yourselves, no matter; for we must not seem to understand him, unless some one among us whom we must produce for an interpreter.

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: No, sir, I warrant you.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: E'en such as you speak to me.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: He must think us some band of strangers i' the adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of all neighbouring languages; therefore we must every one be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we speak one to another; so we seem to know, is to know straight our purpose: choughs' language, gabble enough, and good enough. As for you, interpreter, you must seem very politic. But couch, ho! here he comes, to beguile two hours in a sleep, and then to return and swear the lies he forges.
Enter PAROLLES

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Ten o'clock: within these three hours 'twill be time enough to go home. What shall I say I have done? It must be a very plausive invention that carries it: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces have of late knocked too often at my door. I find my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the fear of Mars before it and of his creatures, not daring the reports of my tongue.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue was guilty of.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: What the devil should move me to undertake the recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in exploit: yet slight ones will not carry it; they will say, 'Came you off with so little?' and great ones I dare not give. Wherefore, what's the instance? Tongue, I must put you into a butter-woman's mouth and buy myself another of Bajazet's mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Is it possible he should know what he is, and be that he is?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I would the cutting of my garments would serve the turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: We cannot afford you so.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in stratagem.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: 'Twould not do.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Hardly serve.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Though I swore I leaped from the window of the citadel.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: How deep?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Thirty fathom.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I would I had any drum of the enemy's: I would swear I recovered it.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: You shall hear one anon.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: A drum now of the enemy's,--
Alarum within

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villiando par corbo, cargo.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: O, ransom, ransom! do not hide mine eyes.
They seize and blindfold him

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I know you are the Muskos' regiment: And I shall lose my life for want of language; If there be here German, or Dane, low Dutch, Italian, or French, let him speak to me; I'll Discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: Boskos vauvado: I understand thee, and can speak thy tongue. Kerely bonto, sir, betake thee to thy faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: O!

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: The general is content to spare thee yet; And, hoodwink'd as thou art, will lead thee on To gather from thee: haply thou mayst inform Something to save thy life.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: O, let me live! And all the secrets of our camp I'll show, Their force, their purposes; nay, I'll speak that Which you will wonder at.

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: But wilt thou faithfully?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: If I do not, damn me.

lines.speaker: first soldier
lines.text: Acordo linta. Come on; thou art granted space.
Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Go, tell the Count Rousillon, and my brother, We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled Till we do hear from them.

lines.speaker: second soldier
lines.text: Captain, I will.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: A' will betray us all unto ourselves: Inform on that.

lines.speaker: second soldier
lines.text: So I will, sir.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Till then I'll keep him dark and safely lock'd.
Exeunt
